author: By Jessica Bennett
title: ‘Accordion Hands’ and ‘Caterpillar Eyebrows’: Trump Meets the Female Gaze
description: Does it matter that the courtroom sketch artists drawing his trial are all women?
content: When Donald Trump is relaxed — or as relaxed as someone can be while on trial for 34 felony counts of falsifying business records — you can see his socks. They are a thin black material, probably cashmere, and you get a glimpse of them only when he leans back in his chair, calves visible over the elastic seam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: N.J. Officials Briefly Close Popular Boardwalk, Citing ‘Civil Unrest’
description: The officials offered few details as to why they declared a state of emergency in Wildwood on one of the busiest weekends of the year.
content: The City of Wildwood, N.J., briefly closed its boardwalk late Sunday, citing “unruly teen crowds” at the bustling beachside attraction during the busy Memorial Day weekend but offering few details about what prompted the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Here Comes Manhattanhenge 2024: When and How to Watch
description: The annual event brings New Yorkers together to celebrate longer days, warmer weather and epic summer sunsets.
content: New Yorkers, get ready for the latest solar spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Spying Arrests Send Chill Through Britain’s Thriving Hong Kong Community
description: Tens of thousands of Hong Kongers have resettled in the U.K. since 2021, among them prominent pro-democracy activists. China has not forgotten them.
content: Simon Cheng still visibly tenses when he describes his detention in China. In 2019, Mr. Cheng, a pro-democracy activist from Hong Kong and a former employee of Britain’s Consulate there, was arrested after a business trip to mainland China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: The Delivery Business Shows Why Unions Are Struggling to Expand
description: The Teamsters union has made little headway in organizing workers at Amazon and FedEx despite wage and other gains it secured at UPS last year.
content: Last year, two unions representing workers at three large automakers and UPS negotiated new labor contracts that included big raises and other gains. Leaders of the unions — the United Automobile Workers and the Teamsters — hoped the wins would help them organize workers across their industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joao Silva
title: The Deadly Prelude to South Africa’s First Free Elections
description: The vote in 1994 was a time of hope — but in the weeks before, the country came close to the abyss. A photographer remembers what he witnessed.
content: Thirty years ago, Black South Africans voted for the first time as the country celebrated the monumental birth of a democracy. As I write this, South Africa is bathed in warm winter sunlight and South Africans are free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Michael C. Bender
title: Trump Elevates a Conservative ‘Warrior’ on Education
description: Byron Donalds is best known as a Trump defender and potential vice-presidential pick. But in Florida, the congressman and his wife made a name — and a business — in the charter school movement.
content: In early 2021, Representative Byron Donalds, Republican of Florida, and his wife, Erika, took the stage at an event hosted by the Truth & Liberty Coalition, a group that pushes to inject Christianity into public schools and other institutions and whose leader has described homosexuality as Satan’s work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Macron says Israeli operations in Rafah ‘must stop,’ and more news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Tuesday Briefing: Netanyahu Calls Rafah Deaths a ‘Tragic Accident’
description: Plus, the toll from the Papua New Guinea landslide
content: The day after an airstrike killed dozens of displaced Palestinians in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, called the deaths a “tragic accident” and accused Hamas of hiding among the general population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bill Walton, N.B.A. Hall of Famer and Broadcasting Star, Dies at 71
description: He won championships in high school, college (U.C.L.A.) and the pros (Trail Blazers and Celtics) before turning to TV as a talkative game analyst in the college ranks.
content: Bill Walton, a center whose extraordinary passing and rebounding skills helped him win two national college championships with U.C.L.A. and one each with the Portland Trail Blazers and Boston Celtics of the N.B.A., and who overcame a stutter to become a loquacious commentator, died on Monday at his home in San Diego. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Michelle Buteau Sashays Into the Lead
description: Once relegated to supporting roles, this comedian is a star of the film “Babes” and is moving to a bigger stage, Radio City Music Hall, for her new special.
content: “Oh my God, are we best friends?” the comedian Michelle Buteau said, 27 seconds into meeting me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can I Wear Neon Without Looking Like a Highlighter?
description: Our fashion critic shares tips for a reader who is hesitant to wear ultrabright clothing.
content: Neon, those blindingly bright colors otherwise associated with traffic cones, sports stars and Las Vegas lights, has been making something of a comeback of late. That’s thanks, in part, to Greta Gerwig’s “Barbie,” complete with Margot Robbie’s neon rollerblading turn, as well as the endless specter of the 1980s and ’90s, when aerobics gave way to acid rock. Type “neon” into Tagwalk, the fashion search engine, and you’ll get 132 looks from the spring men’s and women’s wear shows alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Stanley Goldstein, Who Helped Make CVS a Pharmacy Giant, Dies at 89
description: The small chain that he, a brother and a third partner opened in 1963 had become the nation’s largest by the time he retired as its chief executive three decades later.
content: Stanley P. Goldstein, who in the early 1960s helped start a retail chain named Consumer Value Stores, which, after shortening its name to CVS — because, he said, fewer letters meant cheaper signs — grew into the largest drugstore chain in the United States, died on Tuesday at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen, Keith Bradsher and Jim Tankersley
title: How China Pulled So Far Ahead on Industrial Policy
description: The United States and Europe are trying to catch up to a rival skilled in using all the levers of government and banking to dominate global manufacturing.
content: For more than half a century, concerns about oil shortages or a damaged climate have spurred governments to invest in alternative energy sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: This Island Wants to Round Up Its Wild Goats. Catching Them Won’t Be Easy.
description: The ruminants outnumber humans on the Mediterranean island of Alicudi 6 to 1 (maybe more). Officials have devised a plan to catch the goats and send them to adoptive homes elsewhere.
content: Come June, a crack team of wildlife experts plans to swarm the volcanic cliffs and natural caves of a small island in the Mediterranean to ensnare what has become an out-of-control species: goats gone wild.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Jack Ewing
title: Can Trump Really Slam the Brakes on Electric Vehicles?
description: He has vowed to shred President Biden’s E.V. policies and has threatened that “You won’t be able to sell those cars.”
content: Donald J. Trump is crystal clear about his disdain for electric vehicles. The former president has falsely claimed electric cars don’t work, promised to shred President Biden’s policies that encourage E.V. manufacturing and sales, and has said he would slap a “100 percent tariff” on electric cars imported from Mexico if he retakes the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Damien Cave, Danny Hakim, Brooks Barnes, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Deadly Landslide in Papua New Guinea, and Israeli Strike Kills Dozens in Rafah Camp
description: Plus, the box office battle of “Garfield” and “Furiosa.”
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Stench of Climate Change Denial
description: What overflowing septic tanks tell us about the future.
content: This may sound a bit weird, but when I think about my adolescent years, I sometimes associate them with the faint smell of sewage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Brian Otieno
title: Inside the Factory Supplying Half of Africa’s Syringes
description: In Kenya, Revital Healthcare is manufacturing medical products that Africa needs to take charge of routine health care and respond to outbreaks.
content: On the stunning Kenyan coast, about halfway between 15th-century ruins and the vibrant city of Mombasa, a small factory is helping to achieve one of Africa’s biggest health care goals: self-reliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Ransomware Group Claims Responsibility for Christie’s Hack
description: The hacking group RansomHub is threatening to release “sensitive personal information” about the auction house’s clients.
content: A hacker group called RansomHub said it was behind the cyberattack that hit the Christie’s website just days before its marquee spring sales began, forcing the auction house to resort to alternatives to online bidding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Nicki Minaj Apologizes for Postponed Show After Video Appears to Show Arrest
description: In a video posted live by Minaj to Instagram, the rapper appeared to step into a law enforcement vehicle after being accused of “carrying drugs.”
content: The rapper Nicki Minaj apologized to fans in Manchester, England, for postponing a show scheduled in the city for Saturday night after footage posted to one of her social media accounts appeared to show her being arrested by Dutch authorities for drug possession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel Kweku
title: With Each Basket Steph Curry Shoots, I Inch Closer to Death
description: The Golden State Warriors were young once, and now they’re not.
content: A few weeks ago, as I watched the Golden State Warriors submit to a humiliating defeat by the Sacramento Kings, my main feeling was not frustration, anger or embarrassment. Rather, it was resignation: One day I will die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wadzanai Mhute
title: Soccer Was Out, So He Became a Novelist Instead
description: Chigozie Obioma, the fifth of 12 children in a Nigerian family, dreamed of following in Maradona’s footsteps. Bouts of malaria drove him to books — and changed his life.
content: Chigozie Obioma has made a career of writing, and a very successful one: He has published two novels, both Booker Prize finalists, and has earned about a dozen other awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: U.S. Lawmakers Visit Taiwan and Vow Support in Face of Chinese Military Drills
description: A bipartisan delegation promised to stand by the island’s newly elected president, Lai Ching-te, after Beijing surrounded the self-governing island with naval vessels and aircraft.
content: After China performed two days of military drills intended to punish Taiwan, Representative Michael McCaul of Texas on Monday stood alongside the island nation’s newly elected president, Lai Ching-te, and issued a promise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: Conjuring ‘Bridgerton’ at the Beach
description: Selkie, a brand known for fairy-tale dresses, has expanded into swimwear with bathing suits full of ruffles, ribbons and ruching.
content: These days “cottagecore,” the term for a popular aesthetic in recent years, may bring to mind several things. The early pandemic, say, when cottagecore started to spread rapidly on social media. Or the flouncy dresses, floral motifs, delicate décor and countryside settings that largely defined the aesthetic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Justices’ ‘Disturbing’ Ruling in South Carolina Gerrymandering Case
description: Readers are skeptical of the decision’s argument that the redistricting was not race-based. Also: Questions for Republicans; purebred dogs; chatbot therapy; criticism of Israel.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
title: The Star Witness Who Never Testified at Trump’s Trial
description: Donald J. Trump’s lawyers are expected to highlight the absence of Allen Weisselberg, Mr. Trump’s former finance chief. But he is in jail, serving time for perjury.
content: Days before his inauguration in Washington in 2017, Donald J. Trump had a debt to settle in New York: a payout to his fixer, Michael D. Cohen. They met on the 26th floor of Trump Tower, Mr. Cohen says, and struck a $420,000 deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Onstage, Witches and Cossacks Strike a Chord With Ukrainians
description: A play based on an 19th-century literary classic is a smash hit among Ukrainians who see in the story cultural and historical echoes of what they face after two years of war.
content: The lines for the show snake down the block, with people waiting for up to seven hours to buy tickets at the theater in downtown Kyiv. Videos of the performance have drawn millions of views online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew McCarthy
title: My Life in the Brat Pack, Reconsidered
description: The past can look very different with the passage of time.
content: When I was a very young man, I became very successful very quickly in a string of movies. It was the 1980s, and I was in the right place at the right time as a cultural shift was taking place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,074, May 28, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Musk’s A.I. Firm Raises $6 Billion in Race With Rivals
description: Elon Musk, who founded xAI last year, has said the business “still has a lot of catching up to do” as it looks to compete with well-funded companies like OpenAI.
content: Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence company, xAI, said on Sunday that it had raised $6 billion, helping to close the funding gap with OpenAI, Anthropic and other rivals in the red-hot industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korean Rocket Carrying Spy Satellite Explodes After Takeoff
description: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, has made deploying a fleet of spy satellites one of his country’s latest ​military ambitions.
content: North Korea attempted to put a military reconnaissance satellite into orbit on Monday, the South Korean military said, but the rocket carrying the satellite exploded midair shortly after takeoff, marking the country’s third failed attempt to put a spy satellite into orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Ernesto Londoño
title: Storms Snarl Memorial Day Travel After at Least 23 Killed
description: The weather disrupted flights at airports from Atlanta to Boston on Monday after powerful winds and rain battered towns across the South over the weekend.
content: Severe weather stretching across the Midwest and East Coast on Monday disrupted plans for millions of Americans trying to make it home after a busy weekend that was expected to break records for Memorial Day travel. The disruptions followed storms and tornadoes that killed at least 23 people in the South and left hundreds of thousands without power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Memo to Orchestras: Do More Opera
description: The Cleveland Orchestra’s staging of Mozart’s “The Magic Flute” was a reminder that ensembles can help fill the gap as opera grows harder to find.
content: It was that rarest of sights when I walked into the Cleveland Orchestra’s hall on Sunday afternoon: a dark curtain drawn across the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: What Gen Z Gets Wrong About Sunscreen
description: Surveys suggest young adults are soaking up misinformation about sunscreen and skin cancer. Here are the basics for staying safe.
content: Two new surveys suggest a troubling trend: Young adults seem to be slacking on sun safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond and Christopher Lee
title: She Landed One of Music’s Great Gigs, but First Came Boot Camp
description: Premier military bands offer rare stability for classical musicians, who consider them a strong alternative to traditional orchestras. But signing up means shipping out.
content: The 4,300-seat performance space about an hour north of Carnegie Hall was eerily empty, except for nine judges in uniform sitting behind a thick black curtain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: TikTok Rediscovers an Old Rural Beauty Secret
description: Social media fans of Bag Balm, a moisturizer originally made for cows’ udders, say it’s just the thing for “slugging.”
content: It is the rare item that can be found on the shelves of Tractor Supply and in the pages of Vogue. And now Bag Balm, a moisturizer originally made to heal chapped cows’ udders, is a trending beauty product among the Gen Z “skinfluencers” of TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Pride Events in New York: Here’s How to Celebrate
description: It’s a month of dance parties, film festivals, drag shows and street fairs ahead of the city’s official march on June 30.
content: On June 30, New York City’s official Pride march kicks off around 11 a.m. at 25th Street and Fifth Avenue, with the theme “Reflect. Empower. Unite.” Also that day are PrideFest, the annual street fair in the West Village, and Bliss Days, a celebration of queer women at the DL Rooftop and Lounge. A day earlier, the annual Dyke March takes off from Bryant Park on June 29.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Doesn’t Want You Buying an E.V. From China. Here’s Why.
description: The president wants to shift America’s car fleet toward electric vehicles, but not at the expense of American jobs or national security.
content: President Biden wants more of America’s cars and trucks to run on electricity, not gas. His administration has pushed that goal on multiple fronts, including strict new regulations of auto emissions and lavish new subsidies to help American consumers take as much as $7,500 off the cost of a new electric vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: ‘Bluets’ Review: This Maggie Nelson Adaptation Is All About the Vibes
description: How do you bring an almost plotless book of elliptical fragments to the stage? The director Katie Mitchell has tried with three actors, four screens and three bottles of whiskey.
content: When the Royal Court Theater in London announced it was staging an adaptation of Maggie Nelson’s prose poem memoir “Bluets,” my first reaction was head-scratching surprise. This largely plotless book, in which elliptical fragments of autobiography are entwined with meditations on the cultural history of the color blue and loosely coalesce around the theme of depression, doesn’t exactly scream theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: No Ordinary Music Gig
description: The appeal — and challenges — of being a military musician.
content: Picture the brass section of a symphony orchestra.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 27, 2024
description: No corrections that appeared in print on Monday, May 27, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Brilliant Comic Who Shined Brightest Out of the Spotlight
description: A new biography of the performer, writer and director Elaine May has the intensity to match its subject.
content: Nichols and May, the comedy team, were together from 1957 until 1961. They were so charming and sophisticated and acerbic, selling out Broadway theatres with their crossfire talk, that the critic Edmund Wilson saw them perform four times. He confided to his diary about Elaine May that he was “sorry not to be young enough to fall in love with her and ruin my life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing
description: We’re covering a Ukrainian warning of a new Russian offensive as well as a Hamas strike on Israel.
content: A day after a Russian missile strike on a hardware superstore in Kharkiv, Ukraine, killed at least 16 people, according to officials there, its president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said that Moscow’s forces were massing for a new ground offensive in the northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl and Kristina Samulewski
title: The Cicadas Are Here. You Have Nothing to Fear.
description: An ode to one creature’s brief time in the sun.
content: They’re noisy and clumsy, and there are a trillion of them. Take a stroll with the Opinion contributing writer Margaret Renkl as she shares the sounds of cicadas buzzing and mating in her Nashville neighborhood. For Renkl, these often maligned insects give her great hope and joy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles, Sergio Olmos, Mark Walker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A 100-Ton Locomotive With No One in the Cab
description: Railroad unions are raising safety concerns about the growing use of remote-controlled trains after a rash of fatal accidents.
content: One evening last June, as Esther Iradukunda set the table for dinner at her home in Buffalo, she heard a high-pitched cry through the kitchen window. She rushed outside and followed the screams to the train tracks that ran about 100 feet away from her house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: A Tiny Museum Takes the High Road and Shows the Way Forward
description: Nashville’s Parthenon proves that doing the right thing with looted artifacts doesn’t have to be a fight.
content: When Nashville Scene held its first annual You Are So Nashville If contest in 1989, the winning entry read, “You think our Parthenon is better because the other one fell apart.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pols
title: What’s Love Got to Do With It? This Lusty Tennis Novel May Know.
description: Teddy Wayne takes a swing at sex, class and sporty intrigue in his latest novel, “The Winner.”
content: Emily, one of three women in Teddy Wayne’s seductive sixth novel, “The Winner,” to sleep with Conor O’Toole during his summer as tennis pro in an exclusive gated community near Cape Cod, tells him he’s conventionally handsome — like a political candidate running for office mostly because he looks the part. Or, she says, “someone on a dating show who, I don’t know, sells condos in Florida, and likes jet-skiing, and uses the word badass.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: The Unlikely Women Fighting for Abortion Rights
description: The end of Roe has turned women who terminated pregnancies for medical reasons into a political force.
content: For a long time, many women who had abortions because of catastrophic fetal diagnoses told their stories only privately. Grieving pregnancies they dearly wanted and fearing the stigma of abortion, they sought the closely guarded comfort of online communities identified by the way many doctors had described the procedure — TFMR, or “termination for medical reasons.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Facing Global Outrage, Netanyahu Calls Civilian Deaths in Rafah Strike ‘Tragic Accident’
description: The strike on Sunday, which Israeli officials said targeted two Hamas leaders taking cover near a civilian encampment, ignited a fire that killed 45 people, according to the Gazan authorities.
content: With international condemnation mounting, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Monday that the killing of dozens of people a day earlier at a camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah was “a tragic accident,” but gave no sign of curbing the Israeli offensive in the southern Gaza city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: The Push to Control Plastic Waste in New York: What to Know
description: As plastic continues to fill landfills and oceans, city and state leaders are backing state legislation to curb it.
content: In 2020, the plastic supermarket bag was banned in New York. It is a member of the single-use-plastic family — items that release greenhouse gases when manufactured and, once used, can take years to break down in landfills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Museum Workers Walk Out, Describing Exhibit as Aligned With Zionism
description: The Wing Luke Museum in Seattle temporarily closed after employees criticized an exhibition, saying it wrongly conflated anti-Zionism with antisemitism.
content: The Wing Luke Museum in Seattle remained closed on Monday afternoon, nearly a week after employees walked off the job to protest an exhibition that includes language they believe frames “Palestinian liberation and anti-Zionism as antisemitism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Across New York City, Building Young Dancers On and Off the Stage
description: As Ballet Tech, a tuition-free public school, prepares for its Joyce season, Dionne Figgins teaches the students to see the big picture of their art form.
content: She put up with the giggles for a while, but they would not stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Papua New Guinea Landslide Has Buried 2,000 People, Officials Say
description: Just getting to survivors has proved to be an enormous challenge, with a blocked highway and unstable ground “posing ongoing danger” to rescue workers.
content: More than 2,000 people were buried alive in the landslide that smothered a Papua New Guinea village and work camp on Friday in the country’s remote northern highlands, the authorities told the United Nations on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: China, Japan and South Korea Hold Regional Summit Overshadowed by U.S.
description: In the first trilateral meeting since 2019, the neighbors sought common ground in trade and cultural exchange while tiptoeing around thorny security issues.
content: The leaders of South Korea and Japan on Monday sought to restore economic cooperation with China, their biggest trading partner, after years of souring relations, but their three-way talks were overshadowed by heightened tensions between China and the United States, Seoul and Tokyo’s most important military ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: No, Americans Are Not Completely Stupid About Inflation
description: People may not fully understand the economy, but their feelings about it contain some wisdom.
content: Stefanie Stantcheva was 11 years old in 1997 when annual inflation in Bulgaria, the country from which she and her family had emigrated, surpassed 2,000 percent. “The episode helped shape her eventual decision to study economics,” according to a profile in the International Monetary Fund’s Finance & Development magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 352, May 28, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Michael Gold
title: Libertarians Skip Over Trump and R.F.K. Jr. for Chase Oliver
description: The party selected Mr. Oliver as its presidential nominee. He ran for a Senate seat in Georgia in 2022.
content: The Libertarian Party chose one of its own as its presidential nominee on Sunday night, capping a grueling day of elimination voting and a boisterous four-day event, where both Donald J. Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. unsuccessfully sought to court the group’s backing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Wayne Brady and Nichelle Lewis on Striving for Excellence in ‘The Wiz’
description: The veteran and the newcomer each had their own fears as they joined the Broadway revival of the beloved all-Black musical.
content: “That show was so Black,” my 8-year-old whispered after we saw “The Wiz” on Broadway. He hadn’t made this observation last fall after seeing a performance of the show in Baltimore, during the national tour that preceded this revival. So I was curious: What had changed, and why was this iteration more culturally resonant for him than even the 1978 movie starring Diana Ross and Michael Jackson or NBC’s 2015 “The Wiz Live!” special that I’d screened for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: ‘Delicious, Easy, Healthy and Affordable’
description: Yasmin Fahr’s new recipe for one-pot chicken meatballs with greens is already proving to be a weeknight winner.
content: My family and I have just returned from a weekend in rural Pennsylvania, where we spend every Memorial Day weekend hanging out with good friends, eating enormous platters of grilled meat and veggies, and enjoying the mixed choir of tree frogs and bullfrogs that populate the lake. More reliably than any calendar, that throaty, flirty chorus announces that summer is finally (if unofficially) here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emad Mekay and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Shooting Near Rafah Border Crossing Kills a Member of Egypt’s Security Forces
description: The Israeli military also reported a shooting at the border, where it is fighting Palestinian militants.
content: A member of Egypt’s security forces was killed near the Rafah border crossing with the Gaza Strip and an investigation is underway, an Egyptian army spokesman said on Monday, after the Israeli military reported a shooting on the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $5 Million Homes in California
description: A four-bedroom house with a detached studio in Los Angeles, a 1907 Mediterranean-style home in San Francisco and a French Country-style retreat in Sonoma.
content: This house near the top of Coldwater Canyon was designed by Gerard Colcord, a prolific midcentury architect who offered a traditional alternative to the modernist styles popular in Southern California at the time. It was recently updated by Julia Dempster, an interior designer, with a new kitchen, new bathrooms and new interior paint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Marks
title: Carin León Is Bringing Música Mexicana and Country Ever Closer
description: “There are no limits for music,” the Mexican singer-songwriter said. “There’s just good music and bad music.”
content: In January 2023, the música Mexicana star Carin León was preparing for a concert at Nashville’s Bridgestone Arena when he decided he needed to do something special for an encore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenny Holston
title: A Soldier’s Final Journey Home
description: Sgt. Kennedy Sanders was killed in a drone attack on a U.S. outpost in Jordan. A collection of photos offers a glimpse into her life.
content: “This is what they sent us,” Oneida Sanders said, kneeling beside a heavy wooden chest in her living room. “These are Kennedy’s things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Street Wars: Have E-Bikes Made New York City a ‘Nightmare’?
description: E-bikes zoom down streets, zigzag around cars and zip across sidewalks, changing the way some residents view the streets.
content: Elijah Orlandi knows what many New Yorkers think about delivery workers on e-bikes: They ride too fast. They zigzag in and out of traffic and bike lanes — sometimes going the wrong direction altogether. They materialize on sidewalks, idle in groups and block the paths of pedestrians. They risk colliding with people, pets and cars in their rush to get where they’re going.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: ‘General Hospital’ Actor Reported Killed in Shooting in Los Angeles
description: Johnny Wactor was fatally shot when he interrupted a person who was stealing his vehicle’s catalytic converter, his mother told a news outlet.
content: Johnny Wactor, an actor best known for his role in “General Hospital,” was shot and killed on Saturday, reports said, amid what his family described as an attempted theft of a catalytic converter in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: She Passed the Audition, but Then Came Boot Camp
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 27, 2024.
content: “As you probably know, euphoniums don’t have a lot of options.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Kirchick
title: A Chill Has Fallen Over Jews in Publishing
description: A litmus test has emerged across wide swaths of the literary world, effectively excluding Jews from full participation unless they denounce Israel.
content: This month, an account on X with the handle @moyurireads and 360 followers published a link to a color-coded spreadsheet classifying nearly 200 writers according to their views on the “genocide” in Gaza. Titled “Is Your Fav Author a Zionist?,” it reads like a cross between Tiger Beat and “The Protocols of the Elders of Zion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Marks Memorial Day With Message About Freedom as Trump Lashes Out
description: An earlier message from Donald J. Trump was more traditional, but it was quickly followed by one wishing a happy Memorial Day to “Human Scum.”
content: President Biden paid tribute to veterans who died in America’s wars at Arlington National Cemetery on Monday, hailing them as “a link in the chain of honor” who deserve recognition for protecting the nation’s democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Rivers of Lava on Venus Reveal a More Volcanically Active Planet
description: New software let scientists re-examine old radar images, providing some of the strongest evidence yet that volcanoes continue to reshape the hellish planet.
content: Witnessing the blood-red fires of a volcanic eruption on Earth is memorable. But to see molten rock bleed out of a volcano on a different planet would be extraordinary. That is close to what scientists have spotted on Venus: two vast, sinuous lava flows oozing from two different corners of Earth’s planetary neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mikhail Zygar
title: I’ve Seen How the Biden-Trump Rematch Ends, and It’s Pretty Scary
description: Russia’s election in 1996 is a cautionary tale for America.
content: An elderly president isn’t sure whether he should run for a second term. His approval ratings are low, and there are concerns about his health. His advisers, adamant that he is the only bulwark against a formidable opponent, insist that his candidacy is crucial for the survival of democracy. If he does not run, they say, dictatorship will prevail. Despite his reservations, the president agrees. He pledges to defeat his opponent and protect his country’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Voices Carry at La MaMa, but Only a Few Rise Above the Din
description: The La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival 2024 featured a high ratio of talking to dancing.
content: “You’ll hear our voices, and you’ll see us dance,” the choreographer Arthur Avilés said on Thursday. He was introducing “Naked Vanguard,” his half of one of three double bills in the second week of this year’s La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival. But he could have been speaking about most of the other works sharing the week. The ratio of talking to dancing was especially high, as if to make the low-budget avant-garde more welcoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Lessons from Judge David Tatel’s Guide Dog on Blindness and Vision
description: In a new memoir, a retired federal appeals court judge who was once a leading candidate for the Supreme Court reflects on candor and independence.
content: Had Al Gore won the presidency in 2000, a lot of people thought, he would have put Judge David S. Tatel on the Supreme Court. The judge had a towering intellect, was a model judicial craftsman and, only incidentally, had been blind since his 30s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Elena Shao
title: Access to Aid in Gaza Was Dire. Now, It’s Worse.
description: The amount of food aid and other basic necessities making it into the enclave has shrunk so much that humanitarian officials say their operations are at risk of shutting down.
content: The amount of food aid and other basic necessities making it into the enclave has shrunk so much that humanitarian officials say their operations are at risk of shutting down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Severe Storms and Tornadoes Cause Destruction in Several States
description: Severe weather hit several parts of the United States over the weekend, killing more than 20 people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power.
content: Severe weather hit several parts of the United States over the weekend, killing more than 20 people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Israeli Airstrike at Tent Camp Kills Dozens, Officials Say
description: The Israeli military said the attack was aimed at a Hamas compound, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the civilian deaths “a tragic accident.”
content: The Israeli military said the attack was aimed at a Hamas compound, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the civilian deaths “a tragic accident.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Gazans Look Through Ashes After Israeli Strike on Rafah
description: Displaced Palestinians mourned the dead and sifted through the debris of a tent camp in Rafah, Gaza, that was devastated by an Israeli strike.
content: Displaced Palestinians mourned the dead and sifted through the debris of a tent camp in Rafah, Gaza, that was devastated by an Israeli strike.
source.name: The New York Times
